trans-unit.source: Controls deserialization by the <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer"></xref> class.

During initialization, the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure dynamically generates and compiles a temporary class for deserialization that is derived from the abstract <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> class.

<xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> is also implemented within the .NET Framework for deserialization of XML documents into <xref:System.Web.Services.Discovery.DiscoveryDocument> and <xref:System.Web.Services.Description.ServiceDescription> objects.
You should not derive classes from <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader>.
Instead, call one of the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer.Deserialize%2A> methods.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader"></xref> class.

Stores an object that contains a callback method that will be called, as necessary, to fill in .NET Framework collections or enumerations that map to SOAP-encoded arrays or SOAP-encoded, multi-referenced elements.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.

During initialization, the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure dynamically generates and compiles a temporary class for deserialization that is derived from <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader>.

During this process, the infrastructure generates <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationCollectionFixupCallback> methods and it creates <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader.CollectionFixup> objects to store the fix-up methods and their input data.
The infrastructure does so for SOAP-encoded arrays or SOAP-encoded, multi-referenced elements whose data types, in either case, map to .NET Framework collections or enumerations.
Next, as necessary, the methods are invoked during deserialization to fill in array items or multi-referenced objects.

You should not directly create an instance of the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationCollectionFixupCallback> or <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader.CollectionFixup> class.
A <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationCollectionFixupCallback"></xref> delegate and the callback method's input data.
Stores an object that contains a callback method instance that will be called, as necessary, to fill in the objects in a SOAP-encoded array.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.

While deserializing XML documents into .NET Framework objects, the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure dynamically creates instances of fix-up methods that implement the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationFixupCallback> delegate and creates instances of the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader.Fixup> class to store the fix-up methods and their input data.
The infrastructure does so for SOAP-encoded arrays whose data types map to .NET Framework reference types.
Next, as necessary, a fix-up method is called to fill in the objects in the array.

In addition, during initialization, the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure dynamically generates and compiles a temporary class for deserialization that derives from <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader>.

During this process, the infrastructure generates <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationFixupCallback> methods and <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader.Fixup> objects for SOAP-encoded, multi-referenced XML data.
The methods are then invoked during deserialization.
You should not directly create instances of the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationFixupCallback> or <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader.Fixup> classes.
An <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationFixupCallback"></xref> delegate and the callback method's input data.
Stores an implementation of the <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReadCallback"></xref> delegate and its input data for a later invocation.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.

During initialization, the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure dynamically generates and compiles a temporary class for deserialization that derives from <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader>.
During this process, the .NET Framework generates read methods that implement the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReadCallback> delegate.
It does so for certain mappings between .NET Framework types and XML data types that are serialized through SOAP-encoded XML and are not root elements.
Next, as necessary, a read method is called during deserialization.
You should not directly create an instance of the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReadCallback> class.
The name of the .NET Framework type that is being deserialized.
The namespace of the .NET Framework type that is being deserialized.
The <xref href="System.Type"></xref> to be deserialized.
An <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReadCallback"></xref> delegate.

Stores an object that is being deserialized from a SOAP-encoded `multiRef` element for later access through the <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader.GetTarget(System.String)"></xref> method.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
SOAP encoding allows a unique XML element to appear once within a SOAP message as a `multiRef` element identified by an `id` attribute.
The `id` value can be referenced multiple times by `ref` attributes (or `href` attributes in SOAP 1.1) in substitute elements.
SOAP encoding is described in Section 5 of the SOAP 1.1 specification.
The value of the `id` attribute of a `multiRef` element that identifies the element.
The object that is deserialized from the XML element.
Checks whether the deserializer has advanced.
The method is used by generated classes and should not be directly invoked.

The <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader.CheckReaderCount%2A> method is used when the `checkDeserializerAdvances` attribute of the `<xmlSerializer>` configuration element is set to `true`.
For more information, see [\<xmlSerializer\> Element](~/docs/framework/serialization/xmlserializer-element.md).
The current `count` in a while loop.
The current <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader.ReaderCount"></xref>.
The <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader.ReaderCount"></xref> has not advanced.
Removes all occurrences of white space characters from the beginning and end of the specified string.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
The string that will have its white space trimmed.
The trimmed string.
Creates an <xref href="System.InvalidOperationException"></xref> that indicates that an object being deserialized should be abstract.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended only for use by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
The name of the abstract type.
The .NET Framework namespace of the abstract type.
An <xref href="System.InvalidOperationException"></xref> exception.
Populates an object from its XML representation at the current location of the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref>, with an option to read the inner element.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
The local name of the derived XML Schema data type.
The namespace of the derived XML Schema data type.
The local name of the base XML Schema data type.
The namespace of the base XML Schema data type.
The namespace of the derived .NET Framework type.
The name of the base .NET Framework type.
An <xref href="System.InvalidOperationException"></xref> exception.
Creates an <xref href="System.InvalidOperationException"></xref> that indicates that an object being deserialized cannot be instantiated because the constructor throws a security exception.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
The name of the type.
An <xref href="System.InvalidOperationException"></xref> exception.
Creates an <xref href="System.InvalidOperationException"></xref> that indicates that an object being deserialized cannot be instantiated because there is no constructor available.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
The name of the type.
An <xref href="System.InvalidOperationException"></xref> exception.
Creates an <xref href="System.InvalidCastException"></xref> that indicates that an explicit reference conversion failed.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
The <xref href="System.Type"></xref> that an object cannot be cast to.
This type is incorporated into the exception message.
The object that cannot be cast.
This object is incorporated into the exception message.
An <xref href="System.InvalidCastException"></xref> exception.
Creates an <xref href="System.InvalidCastException"></xref> that indicates that an explicit reference conversion failed.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
The <xref href="System.Type"></xref> that an object cannot be cast to.
This type is incorporated into the exception message.
The object that cannot be cast.
This object is incorporated into the exception message.
A string identifier.
An <xref href="System.InvalidCastException"></xref> exception.
Creates an <xref href="System.InvalidOperationException"></xref> that indicates that a derived type that is mapped to an XML Schema data type cannot be located.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
The local name of the XML Schema data type that is mapped to the unavailable derived type.
The namespace of the XML Schema data type that is mapped to the unavailable derived type.
The full name of the .NET Framework base type for which a derived type cannot be located.
An <xref href="System.InvalidOperationException"></xref> exception.
Creates an <xref href="System.InvalidOperationException"></xref> that indicates that a SOAP-encoded collection type cannot be modified and its values cannot be filled in.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
The fully qualified name of the .NET Framework type for which there is a mapping.
An <xref href="System.InvalidOperationException"></xref> exception.
Creates an <xref href="System.InvalidOperationException"></xref> that indicates that an enumeration value is not valid.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
The enumeration value that is not valid.
The enumeration type.
An <xref href="System.InvalidOperationException"></xref> exception.
Creates an <xref href="System.InvalidOperationException"></xref> that indicates that the current position of <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref> represents an unknown XML node.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
An <xref href="System.InvalidOperationException"></xref> exception.
Creates an <xref href="System.InvalidOperationException"></xref> that indicates that a type is unknown.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
An <xref href="System.Xml.XmlQualifiedName"></xref> that represents the name of the unknown type.
An <xref href="System.InvalidOperationException"></xref> exception.
Gets or sets a value that determines whether XML strings are translated into valid .NET Framework type names.
The <xref:System.Xml.XmlConvert.EncodeName%2A> method writes valid XML from invalid sources.
For example, the <xref:System.Data.DataColumn.ColumnName%2A> property of the <xref:System.Data.DataColumn> class can contain spaces, which are invalid as XML.
The <xref:System.Xml.XmlConvert.DecodeName%2A> reads the encoded XML and restores it to the original value.
However, the <xref:System.Xml.Schema.XmlSchema.Read%2A> method of the <xref:System.Xml.Schema.XmlSchema> class cannot read such encoded XML.
In that case, set the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationWriter.EscapeName%2A> property to `false` to disable the encoding of the XML.
`true` if XML strings are decoded into valid .NET Framework type names; otherwise, `false`.
Gets the XML document object into which the XML document is being deserialized.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
An <xref href="System.Xml.XmlDocument"></xref> that represents the deserialized <xref href="System.Xml.XmlDocument"></xref> data.
Ensures that a given array, or a copy, is large enough to contain a specified index.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
The <xref href="System.Array"></xref> that is being checked.
The required index.
The <xref href="System.Type"></xref> of the array's elements.
The existing <xref href="System.Array"></xref>, if it is already large enough; otherwise, a new, larger array that contains the original array's elements.
Fills in the values of a SOAP-encoded array whose data type maps to a .NET Framework reference type.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.

The <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader.FixupArrayRefs%2A> method implements the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationFixupCallback> delegate for deserialization of SOAP-encoded XML data.

While deserializing XML documents into .NET Framework objects, the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure dynamically creates an instance of the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader.FixupArrayRefs%2A> method for SOAP-encoded arrays whose data types map to .NET Framework reference types.
The method then is called by <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationFixupCallback> to fill in the objects in the array.
SOAP encoding is described in Section 5 of the SOAP 1.1 specification.
An object that contains the array whose values are filled in.
Gets the length of the SOAP-encoded array where the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref> is currently positioned.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.

The <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader.GetArrayLength%2A> method applies to the `arrayType` attribute that is used with SOAP encoding and specified with the namespace "http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/".
The local name that the array should have.
The namespace that the array should have.
The length of the SOAP array.
Determines whether the XML element where the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref> is currently positioned has a null attribute set to the value `true`.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
`true` if <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref> is currently positioned over a null attribute with the value `true`; otherwise, `false`.

Gets an object that is being deserialized from a SOAP-encoded `multiRef` element and that was stored earlier by <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader.AddTarget(System.String,System.Object)"></xref>.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
SOAP encoding allows a unique XML element to appear once within a SOAP message as a `multiRef` element identified by an `id` attribute.
The `id` value can be referenced multiple times using `href` attributes (or `ref` attributes in SOAP 1.2) in substitute elements.
SOAP encoding is described in Section 5 of the SOAP 1.1 specification.
The value of the `id` attribute of a `multiRef` element that identifies the element.
An object to be deserialized from a SOAP-encoded `multiRef` element.
Gets the value of the `xsi:type` attribute for the XML element at the current location of the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref>.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
The `type` attribute from the instance of the XML Schema namespace explicitly specifies the data type of an XML element.
An XML qualified name that indicates the data type of an XML element.
Initializes callback methods that populate objects that map to SOAP-encoded XML data.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.

During initialization, the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure dynamically generates and compiles a temporary class for deserialization that is derived from <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader>.
During this process, the .NET Framework generates read methods that implement the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReadCallback> delegate.
It does so for certain mappings between .NET Framework types and XML data types that are serialized through SOAP-encoded XML and are not root elements.
Next, as necessary, a read method is called during deserialization.
The abstract <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader.InitCallbacks%2A> method is where the temporary derived class creates an instance of and initializes read callback methods.
You should not directly create an instance of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReadCallback>.
SOAP encoding is described in Section 5 of the SOAP 1.1 specification.
Stores element and attribute names in a <xref href="System.Xml.NameTable"></xref> object.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
The <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader.InitIDs%2A> method is abstract.
Gets or sets a value that should be `true` for a SOAP 1.1 return value.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
`true`, if the value is a return value.
Determines whether an XML attribute name indicates an XML namespace.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
An attribute name indicates an XML namespace if it takes the form `xmlns:key`, where "key" is the namespace name.
The name of an XML attribute.
`true` if the XML attribute name indicates an XML namespace; otherwise, `false`.
Sets the value of the XML attribute if it is of type `arrayType` from the Web Services Description Language (WSDL) namespace.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
WSDL uses the namespace "http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/wsdl/".
An <xref href="System.Xml.XmlAttribute"></xref> that may have the type `wsdl:array`.
Makes the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref> read the fully qualified name of the element where it is currently positioned.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
The fully qualified name of the current XML element.
Makes the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref> read an XML end tag.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
Gets the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref> object that is being used by <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader"></xref>.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
The <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref> that is being used by the <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader"></xref>.
Gets the current count of the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref>.
The method is used by generated classes and should not be directly invoked.
The <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> uses an instance of the <xref:System.Xml.XmlReader> class to count when a read operation occurs.
The count is incremented each time the reader calls an appropriate method, for example the <xref:System.Xml.XmlReader.Read%2A> method or the <xref:System.Xml.XmlReader.ReadElementString%2A> method.
The current count of an <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref>.
Instructs the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref> to read the current XML element if the element has a null attribute with the value true.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
`true` if the element has a **null="true"** attribute value and has been read; otherwise, `false`.
Instructs the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref> to read the fully qualified name of the element where it is currently positioned.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
A <xref href="System.Xml.XmlQualifiedName"></xref> that represents the fully qualified name of the current XML element; otherwise, `null` if a **null="true"** attribute value is present.
Instructs the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref> to read a simple, text-only XML element that could be `null`.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
The string value; otherwise, `null`.
Reads the value of the `href` attribute (`ref` attribute for SOAP 1.2) that is used to refer to an XML element in SOAP encoding.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
The opening `#` symbol is stripped from the `href` attribute value.
SOAP encoding allows a unique XML element to appear once within a SOAP message as a `multiRef` element identified by an `id` attribute.
The `id` value can be referenced multiple times using `href` attributes (or `ref` attributes in SOAP 1.2) in substitute elements.
SOAP encoding is described in Section 5 of the SOAP 1.1 specification.
An output string into which the `href` attribute value is read.
`true` if the value was read; otherwise, `false`.
Deserializes an object from a SOAP-encoded `multiRef` XML element.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
The <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader.ReadReferencedElement%2A> method obtains the XML Schema data type by reading the `xsi:type` attribute of the `multiRef` element.
The prefix `xsi` refers to the instance of the XML Schema namespace.
SOAP encoding allows a unique XML element to appear once within a SOAP message as a `multiRef` element identified by an `id` attribute.
The `id` value can be referenced multiple times using `href` attributes (or `ref` attributes in SOAP 1.2) in substitute elements.
SOAP encoding is described in Section 5 of the SOAP 1.1 specification.
The value of the referenced element in the document.
Deserializes an object from a SOAP-encoded `multiRef` XML element.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.

This signature of the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader.ReadReferencedElement%2A> method obtains the XML Schema data type of the `multiRef` element from the method parameters rather than by reading the `xsi:type` attribute.
The prefix `xsi` refers to the instance of the XML Schema namespace.
SOAP encoding allows a unique XML element to appear once within a SOAP message as a `multiRef` element identified by an `id` attribute.
The `id` value can be referenced multiple times using `href` attributes (or `ref` attributes in SOAP 1.2) in substitute elements.
SOAP encoding is described in Section 5 of the SOAP 1.1 specification.
The local name of the element's XML Schema data type.
The namespace of the element's XML Schema data type.
The value of the referenced element in the document.
Deserializes objects from the SOAP-encoded `multiRef` elements in a SOAP message.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
SOAP encoding allows a unique XML element to appear once within a SOAP message as a `multiRef` element identified by an `id` attribute.
The `id` value can be referenced multiple times using `href` attributes (or `ref` attributes in SOAP 1.2) in substitute elements.
SOAP encoding is described in Section 5 of the SOAP 1.1 specification.
Deserializes an object from an XML element in a SOAP message that contains a reference to a `multiRef` element.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
SOAP encoding allows a unique XML element to appear once within a SOAP message as a `multiRef` element identified by an `id` attribute.
The `id` value can be referenced multiple times using `href` attributes (or `ref` attributes in SOAP 1.2) in substitute elements.
SOAP encoding is described in Section 5 of the SOAP 1.1 specification.
An output string into which the `href` attribute value is read.
The deserialized object.
Deserializes an object from an XML element in a SOAP message that contains a reference to a `multiRef` element.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
SOAP encoding allows a unique XML element to appear once within a SOAP message as a `multiRef` element identified by an `id` attribute.
The `id` value can be referenced multiple times using `href` attributes (or `ref` attributes in SOAP 1.2) in substitute elements.
SOAP encoding is described in Section 5 of the SOAP 1.1 specification.
The local name of the element's XML Schema data type.
The namespace of the element's XML Schema data type.
An output string into which the `href` attribute value is read.
The deserialized object.
Deserializes an object from an XML element in a SOAP message that contains a reference to a `multiRef` element.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
SOAP encoding allows a unique XML element to appear once within a SOAP message as a `multiRef` element identified by an `id` attribute.
The `id` value can be referenced multiple times using `href` attributes (or `ref` attributes in SOAP 1.2) in substitute elements.
SOAP encoding is described in Section 5 of the SOAP 1.1 specification.
The local name of the element's XML Schema data type.
The namespace of the element's XML Schema data type.
`true` if the element name is also the XML Schema data type name; otherwise, `false`.
An output string into which the value of the `href` attribute is read.
The deserialized object.
Populates an object from its XML representation at the current location of the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref>.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
An <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.IXmlSerializable"></xref> that corresponds to the current position of the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref>.
An object that implements the <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.IXmlSerializable"></xref> interface with its members populated from the location of the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref>.
This method supports the .NET Framework infrastructure and is not intended to be used directly from your code.
An IXmlSerializable object that corresponds to the current position of the XMLReader.
Specifies whether the serializable object is wrapped.
An object that implements the IXmlSerializable interface with its members populated from the location of the XmlReader.

Returns the result of a call to the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader.ReadString"></xref> method of the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref> class, trimmed of white space if needed, and appended to the input value.
A string that will be appended to.
`true` if the result of the read operation should be trimmed; otherwise, `false`.
The result of the read operation appended to the input value.
Produces the result of a call to the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader.ReadString"></xref> method appended to the input value.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
A string to prefix to the result of a call to the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader.ReadString"></xref> method.
The result of call to the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader.ReadString"></xref> method appended to the input value.
Reads an XML element that allows null values (`xsi:nil = 'true'`) and returns a generic <xref href="System.Nullable`1"></xref> value.
The <xref href="System.Xml.XmlQualifiedName"></xref> that represents the simple data type for the current location of the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref>.
A generic <xref href="System.Nullable`1"></xref> that represents a null XML value.
Gets the value of the XML node at which the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref> is currently positioned.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
`true` if the method should read content only after reading the element's start element; otherwise, `false`.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
`true` to read content only after reading the element's start element; otherwise, `false`.

Stores an object to be deserialized from a SOAP-encoded `multiRef` element.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
SOAP encoding allows a unique XML element to appear once within a SOAP message as a `multiRef` element identified by an `id` attribute.
The `id` value can be referenced multiple times using `href` attributes (or `ref` attributes in SOAP 1.2) in substitute elements.
SOAP encoding is described in Section 5 of the SOAP 1.1 specification.
The object to be deserialized.
Gets a dynamically generated assembly by name.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
The <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader.ResolveDynamicAssembly%2A> method is static.
The full name of the assembly.
A dynamically generated <xref href="System.Reflection.Assembly"></xref>.
Ensures that a given array, or a copy, is no larger than a specified length.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.
The array that is being checked.
The maximum length of the array.
The <xref href="System.Type"></xref> of the array's elements.
`true` if `null` for the array, if present for the input array, can be returned; otherwise, a new, smaller array.
The existing , if it is already small enough; otherwise, a new, smaller array that contains the original array's elements up to the size of length.
Produces a base-64 byte array from an input string.

A string to translate into a base-64 byte array.
A base-64 byte array.

A comma-delimited list of XML qualified names.

The <xref href="System.Object"></xref> that is being deserialized.

Raises an <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer.UnknownNode"></xref> event for the current position of the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref>.
The object that is being deserialized.
Raises an <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer.UnreferencedObject"></xref> event for the current position of the <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref>.

The protected members of <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializationReader> are intended for use only by derived classes that are used internally within the .NET Framework XML serialization infrastructure.

SOAP encoding, as specified in Section 5 of the SOAP 1.1 specification, allows for elements referenced multiple times in a SOAP message (or optionally, just once) to be referred by an `href` attribute in the main message.
An <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer.UnreferencedObject> event occurs when such an element appears, but there is no `href` reference to it.

Add a handler method to <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer.UnreferencedObject> to provide custom handling for unreferenced objects while the <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer> executes its <xref:System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer.Deserialize%2A> method.

A unique string that is used to identify the unreferenced object, subsequently accessible through the <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.UnreferencedObjectEventArgs.UnreferencedId"></xref> property.

An object that the <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer"></xref> is attempting to deserialize, subsequently accessible through the <xref href="System.Xml.Serialization.UnreferencedObjectEventArgs.UnreferencedObject"></xref> property.
